Award.AwardTitle: Development of a Concept Inventory for Functional Reasoning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project at the University of Illinois at Chicago will help to improve the ability of engineering students to design technological products by creating and testing a means to assess functional reasoning capabilities. Functional reasoning is the ability to conceive of a task required in an engineering design problem as accomplished by a set of steps or functions. Functional reasoning allows engineers to decompose a mechanical system and correctly analyze it in terms of the functions performed by its subsystems and features. This project will develop a validated method to assess student understanding of function. Assessment of functional reasoning ability will improve engineering education and increase retention of students in engineering by helping faculty to more precisely determine the nature of the difficulties some students have in developing functional reasoning skills. The work will include a collaboration between faculty at the University of Illinois at Chicago and faculty at community colleges.

This work will develop and validate a concept inventory for functional reasoning as a means to help promote thoughtful and effective teaching of functional reasoning to undergraduate students. Project personnel will apply accepted best practices in the development of the concept inventory. The approach will use Delphi study methods as a structured means to solicit information from experts in the content of functional design methods. While engineering function is often covered in senior-level engineering courses, this project will consider the teaching of functional reasoning in the context of design courses for first year engineering students. The project team anticipates that facility with functional reasoning may correlate with certain demographic variables; and a diverse and well-educated pool of engineers will depend upon a thoughtful, considered approach to teaching and learning about function. The project team includes engineering faculty with expertise in engineering design methodologies as well as collaborators from the learning sciences. The outcome of the work will be a concept inventory to assess functional reasoning ability in engineering students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project Number 1504851, Development of a Concept Inventory for Functional Reasoning, worked towards the development of a concept inventory for functional reasoning in engineering design. A concept inventory is a test that is used to determine if someone understands a concept or a set of concepts. This is usually a multiple-choice test in which the incorrect answers to a question help to identify if students have misconceptions that are known to be common among those learning the subject. Functional reasoning is thinking and describing objects or systems abstractly in terms of the functions they perform rather than in terms of their physical structure. Functional reasoning is essential to designing things and solving problems as an engineer, as it is how an engineer describes what needs to be done without assuming how the solution will be accomplished. Indeed, one can say that functional reasoning is fundamental to thinking like an engineer. Despite its importance in engineering design, engineering instructors do not in general know whether or not their students understand these concepts.

Other concept inventories have been developed using a Delphi method in which a panel of experts is assembled to offer opinions about the concepts that should be included. In the Delphi process, the panelists remain anonymous from each other so that all panelists provide honest opinions. The research team conducted three rounds of anonymous surveys/interviews with the panelists. The first round was intended to obtain a list of possible concepts to include in a concept inventory, and the next two rounds were used to refine and rank these concepts on the basis of their importance and difficulty. Following the standard Delphi process, panelists did not interact directly, but at each round the research team made available to all panelists a summary of input from the prior rounds.

A particularly interesting result of this project was that the Delphi panel had great difficulty in producing an initial list of concepts that define functional reasoning. Most panelists did not provide any concepts for consideration, and there was relatively little consensus among those who did provide lists. This was in contrast to work on concept inventories in other technical fields reported in the literature, in which the Delphi panel quickly provided a full set of candidate concepts. The research team thus augmented the list of concepts from the Delphi panel with concepts discussed in the engineering literature.

Once a list of candidate concepts was established, the Delphi panel provided two rounds of feedback on these concepts, judging them according to their importance and difficulty. A concept inventory should include concepts that are both important and difficult. The result of the Delphi process was a list of fifty concepts in twelve categories, ranked according to importance and difficulty. Sixteen of these concepts across ten categories seem particularly promising for further development.

The project set out to build a concept inventory for an accepted set of concepts in the field of functional reasoning. It turned out that no such accepted set of concepts seemed to exist, and the results of this project would be more fundamental than anticipated -- rather than developing an assessment instrument for an existing set of concepts, the main results of the project would be to help define what those concepts are, or should be, in the first place.

Project results were published and presented at regional and national engineering design conferences. Engineering design is an important driver of societal welfare, and the education of engineers is crucial both to develop new technologies and to maintain existing technological and economic infrastructure. Engineering design courses continue to teach functional reasoning procedures. The results of this project help to move the field towards a more comprehensive understanding of functional reasoning and how students learn it.
